results.notes: Charlotte, North Carolina, USA. Discovered nearby a walking trail and 10 meters from a pond in mixed woods litter. Flesh of cap (120mm dia) and stipe (20mm dia 35mm len) is firm and the stipe seems to be softer in the center. I first thought Lactarius or similar but did not evidence milk when sliced. The gills stained brown at the edges and the bruises stained light brown elsewhere. Spore print is white to cream. Taste seemed mealy but I don’t trust my taste due to sinus damage. Smell is like Pleurotus at the gills but indistinct on fresh broken flesh. I have trudged through the KUO keys on four paths but find little joy for confidence. Any opinion or knowledge is appreciated.
results.location_name: Southeast Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

results.notes:
Growing from bamboo litter near stream, presumably from buried wood (Inga, Artocarpus in vicinity) Stipe 32 cm long! Context light colored and generally homogenous but with growth zones, no melanoid bands. Strongly amyloid pileocystidia. Pileocystidia mostly even, regular, unbranched, appearing to be about 40-50 um long. Spores about 8-10 × 5-7 um (pillars don’t appear free like ‘subamboinense’ but generally shape and size agree). Thick walled, hyaline, guttalate, ovoid (chlamydospores?) observed in trama slide, about 11×15um, where one would expect them to be only among the context.

—

results.notes:
Cap color best represented by photo #8. Photo #9 emphasizes yellow/brown and de-emphasizes grayish/olivaceous tones seen in photo #8.

Narrow trail throurh oak woods.

Spores mainly globose, some subglobose, 11-12 × 10.5-11.5.

Color scheme on the cap is reminiscent of A. luzernensis, as is the relatively large size for a fruit body representing section Vaginatae. Differences are: 1. The cap seen in this observation lacks the small but rather abrupt umbo; 2. The stipe seen here lacks the grayish patchy ornamentation (here it is white). 3. The spores for this collection are larger than I had previously seen. 4. The occurrence of this current observation is earlier in the season than collections of A. luzernensis (and this year 2020 is a particularly slow-to-start season for mycorrhizal fungi in NE PA).

results.notes:
Leratiomyces ceres (Agaricales, Strophariaceae) Bogotá, Colombia

Primer registro de esta especie para el país, determinado el 5/06/2016 por Chivatá Teodoro y Arias Camila, en el Humedal La Conejera Bogotá, Colombia.

2014-2020, Registros
https://colombia.inaturalist.org/...
2016, Publicación
https://www.researchgate.net/...
2020, Recopilación
https://mushroomobserver.org/414059?q=1JArw

A continuación, se realiza su respectiva descripción: basidioma estipitado, lignicola, principalmente gregario, en ocasiones solitario o cespitado, no higrofano, píleo de 5 a 7 cm de diámetro, hemisférico en un principio, luego pasa a ser plano convexo con el centro umbonado, orbicular (vista apical). Margen recto, entero y ligeramente ondulado, de superficie glabra, viscida y brillosa, que luego pasa a ser seca y opaca, de color rojo que tiende a oscurecerse con el tiempo, con escamas blancas y fasciculadas en el margen, originadas por restos del velo universal. Himenio con lamelas y lamélulas, se encuentran próximas entre sí (apretadas), adnadas a ligeramente uncinadas, anchas, de borde liso, lamélulas atenuadas, de color café claro principio, después gris violáceo y finalmente púrpura negruzco, arista entera, blanquecina. Contexto homegeneo y hueco. Esporada de color marron oscuro.

Estípite de 4-8 cm de largo x 0.4-0.5 cm de ancho, cilíndrico, central, sub-bulboso y con tomento basal con cordones miceliares (rizomorfos), de color blanco con zonas de color naranja rojizo que se intensifica con el tiempo, de superficie pruinosa. Se engrosa ligeramente hacia la base. En algunos ejemplares se logra observar un anillo en banda (rudimentario) adherido al estípite, delgado y efimero. De consistencia fibrosa. Sin olor o sabor apreciable. Basidiosporas elipsoidales, lisas, de paredes gruesas, con poro germinal.

El trabajo de microscopia se realizó con un Microscopio Zeiss de Luz Halogena 6v 30w y reactivos rojo congo, melzer e hidróxido de potasio (KOH) 5%. Se observan basidios tetraspóricos, claviformes de 31 × 8 µm, basidiosporas elipsoidales no amiloides, de color marrón a rojo oscuro, superficie lisa, ligeramente apiculadas, con poro germinativo evidente (0,8 a 1 µm). Cistidios fusiformes, de 35,7 × 12,7 µm en general se observan hifas paralelas y presencia de fíbulas.

Appears to be amanita genus but unable to identify specific species.

results.notes:
Habitat: in bottomland mixed woods growing among clubmosses, nearby trees included Pinus strobus, Quercus rubra, Carya sp, Betula lenta, and Liriodendron tulipifera
Cap: diameter 62 mm, flat with a rounded umbo, slightly tacky, blackish brown over the disc, quickly paling to grayish brown peripherally, not zonate. Margins ragged, striations 10-14 mm long, not notably tuberculate
Gills: close, free, white, short gills occasional, truncate, edges finely serrate
Stipe: 134 mm long, 7 mm wide near apex, 9 mm wide above volval sac, white with white fibrils on lower half, hollow, no partial veil. Volval sac well developed, fairly sturdy, white with the interior of the free limb pale gray
Flesh: white
Odor and Taste: both not distinctive
Spore print: white
Note: the cap of this specimen resembles a mushroom Tulloss has temporarily called “Amanita cyclops.” Another of his nom provs, A. blueridgensis, has a paler umbo and narrower spores.

results.notes:
Co-inhabiting leaf spots with Lophodermium schweinitzii on Rhododendron maximum understory in Tsuga, Betula, Quercus, Fagus forest.
Photos and measurements five days after incubation. Apothecia fruiting on bleached out spots without a prominent border line. One spot with a yellow halo. Asexual pycnidia present but dried up. Fruit bodies dehiscence into five angles displaying a pale yellow hymenium when fresh. Apothecia with a covering stroma ~ 25 um thick and proper exipulum ~23 um w layers of septate hyphae. Spores have an inconspicuous slime sheath.
Asci strongly cylindrical with little apical or mid swelling.
Paraphyses filiform, enveloped in a gel in which they adhere together, nonseptate with a non curling apical swelling width measuring in H20 4.7, 4, 5.1, 4.8, 4, 3.5 um.
Asci measured in H20 135 × 7.5, 133.4 × 8.6, 135 × 6.5, 127 × 6, 144 × 7.3
Spore measure in H20 105 × 1.6, 94 × 1.3, 91 × 2, 89 × 2, 109 × 2
results.location_name: Hickory Run State Park, Carbon Co., Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes:
Sharing leaf spots with Coccomyces radiatus on Rhododendron maximum understory in Tsuga, Betula, Quercus, Fagus forest.
6-26-20- After five days incubation hysterothecia not mature with stubby, broad asci rarely present with no spores.
7-6-20- Ascomata degraded and still immature after two weeks of incubation. Asci short and broad with an acute apex. Paraphyses filiform w no swelling.

results.notes:
Growing singly in hardwood leaf litter next to a hardwood log. Cap hygrophanous. Basal mycelium white. Gills purple-marginate. Lamellar trama vinescent. Clamps present in the lamellar trama. Cheilocystidia smooth, hyaline and fusoid. Pleurocystidia similar to the cheilocystidia. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores weakly amyloid, smooth and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (5.9) 6.3 – 7.6 (8.4) × (3) 3.1 – 3.7 (3.9) µm, Q = (1.7) 1.8 – 2.2 (2.5); N = 30, Me = 7 × 3.4 µm; Qe = 2.1
